claim_text: 9.2 billion tons of plastic produced between 1950 and 2017
400 million tons of plastics produced per year in 2022, estimated to reach 590 million tons by 2050
Microplastics found in Raritan and Passaic rivers in NJ; stormwater identified as primary contributor
Indoor air can have microplastic concentrations 100 times greater than outdoor air
Collaborative study with Columbia University found hundreds of thousands of nanoplastic particles in three brands of bottled water
citations: Columbia University collaboration using specialized microscopy

claim_text: Nanoplastics in bottled water not derived from packaging or cap, but from upstream sources (filtration or source water)
Tea bags and hot container cups can release trillions of nanoplastic particles during single use
citations: National Institute of Standards and Technology

claim_text: Microplastics identified in human lung, liver, kidney, urine, feces, heart, placenta, blood, and breast milk
Hawaii placenta samples: 60% contained microplastics in 2006, 90% in 2013, 100% in 2021
Nanoplastics identified in placenta and fetal tissues (lung, heart, kidney, liver, brain) within 24 hours after exposure in rat models
Particles persist in offspring for minimum of six months in rodent studies
Microplastics in fecal matter associated with increased severity of inflammatory bowel disease
New England Journal of Medicine March 2024: Micro/nanoplastics in carotid plaque correlated with increased inflammation and cardiovascular risk
citations: New England Journal of Medicine, March 2024

claim_text: Less than 10% of plastics are actually recycled nationally (5-6% according to DOE/EPA)
In 1950, 2 million tons of plastic produced per year; now 450 million tons per year
Microplastics in carotid plaque correlated with 4-fold increased risk of cardiac incident (heart attack, stroke, premature death)
citations: New England Journal of Medicine study

claim_text: By 2030, for every 3 pounds of fish in ocean there will be 1 pound of plastic; by 2050 ratio will be 1:1 without policy change
NJ exports second-most plastic to other countries after California
Chemical recycling handles only 1.3% of total plastic generated in US
Bottle bill states: aluminum can recycling 77% vs 36% in non-bottle-bill states
Bottle bill states: glass bottle recycling 66% vs 22%
Bottle bill states: PET plastic bottle recycling 57% vs 17%
Plastics have 16,000 different chemicals, making recycling fundamentally difficult
More than 15,000 chemicals used to manufacture plastics; 25% classified as chemicals of concern; 40% have unknown health risks
National Toxicology Program 2000: Phthalates fed to pregnant rats caused measurable changes in reproductive systems of male pups (Phthalate Syndrome)
Personal research demonstrated Phthalate Syndrome in human male infants (published 2005, replicated in second study)
Research influenced Consumer Protection Act of 2008 after Congressional testimony
Worldwide sperm counts have declined 50% since 1970 (about 1% per year)
2023 update: Rate of sperm count decline has accelerated, not leveled off
Total fertility rate has declined worldwide at same rate as sperm count: 1% per year (World Bank data)
Number of endangered species more than doubled between 2007 and 2022
South Korea fertility rate now 0.8 children per couple (replacement requires 2.1)
California study: 28-day reduction in EDC-containing personal care products reduced genetic markers predicting breast cancer progression
California Prop 65 has listed over 900 chemicals as known or potential endocrine disruptors
NJ recovered 113,000 tons plastic containers + 14,000 tons plastic scrap = 127,000 tons total in most recent year
75% overall container recycling rate in NJ; 57% plastic container recycling rate
Average 133,000 tons of plastics recovered per year over past 5 years in NJ
1.67 metric tons CO2 equivalents avoided for every ton of MSW recycled (EPA)
For every pound of recycled PET used in lieu of virgin material, GHG emissions reduced by 71%
NJ has 23 MRFs (material recovery facilities) processing recyclables
Average disposal cost $90/ton vs plastics revenue exceeds $300/ton - economic incentive is real
Approximately 10% residue (non-recyclable material) in recycling stream
